Physical Chemistry.name: Boyle's Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes the inverse relationship between pressure and volume of a gas at constant moles and temperature.

example.problem: \text{A gas occupies } 2.0 \text{ L at a pressure of } 1.5 \text{ atm. Calculate the volume if the pressure is increased to } 3.0 \text{ atm at constant temperature.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Boyle's Law: } P_1 V_1 &= P_2 V_2 \\
1.5 \cdot 2.0 &= 3.0 \cdot V_2 \\
3.0 &= 3.0 V_2 \\
V_2 &= \frac{3.0}{3.0} = 1.0 \text{ L} \\
\text{Thus, the new volume is } 1.0 \text{ L} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Charles' Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes the direct relationship between volume and temperature of a gas at constant moles and pressure.

example.problem: \text{A gas has a volume of } 3.0 \text{ L at } 300 \text{ K. What is the volume at } 450 \text{ K if pressure remains constant?}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Charles' Law: } \frac{V_1}{T_1} &= \frac{V_2}{T_2} \\
\frac{3.0}{300} &= \frac{V_2}{450} \\
0.01 &= \frac{V_2}{450} \\
V_2 &= 0.01 \cdot 450 = 4.5 \text{ L} \\
\text{Thus, the new volume is } 4.5 \text{ L} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Avogadro's Law
Physical Chemistry.description: States that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles at constant pressure and temperature.

example.problem: \text{A gas occupies } 5.0 \text{ L with } 0.2 \text{ mol. What is the volume if } 0.3 \text{ mol is added at constant } P \text{ and } T?}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Avogadro's Law: } \frac{V_1}{n_1} &= \frac{V_2}{n_2} \\
\text{New moles: } n_2 &= 0.2 + 0.3 = 0.5 \text{ mol} \\
\frac{5.0}{0.2} &= \frac{V_2}{0.5} \\
25 &= \frac{V_2}{0.5} \\
V_2 &= 25 \cdot 0.5 = 12.5 \text{ L} \\
\text{Thus, the new volume is } 12.5 \text{ L} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Ideal Gas Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Relates pressure, volume, amount, and temperature of an ideal gas.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the pressure of } 0.5 \text{ mol of an ideal gas in a } 2.0 \text{ L container at } 300 \text{ K, given } R = 0.08206 \text{ L·atm/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
PV &= nRT \\
P \cdot 2.0 &= 0.5 \cdot 0.08206 \cdot 300 \\
P \cdot 2.0 &= 12.309 \\
P &= \frac{12.309}{2.0} \approx 6.1545 \text{ atm} \\
\text{Thus, the pressure is approximately } 6.15 \text{ atm} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Gas Constant Calculation
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the gas constant from standard temperature and pressure (STP) conditions.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } R \text{ for } 1.0 \text{ mol of gas occupying } 22.414 \text{ L at } 1.0 \text{ atm and } 273.15 \text{ K (STP).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Density of Gas
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the density of a gas under given conditions.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the density of } \text{O}_2 \text{ (} M = 32.00 \text{ g/mol) at } 2.0 \text{ atm and } 300 \text{ K, given } R = 0.08206 \text{ L.atm/(mol.K)}.

Physical Chemistry.name: Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures
Physical Chemistry.description: The total pressure of a gas mixture is the sum of the partial pressures of its components.

example.problem: \text{A mixture contains } \text{N}_2 \text{ at } 0.8 \text{ atm and } \text{O}_2 \text{ at } 0.6 \text{ atm. Calculate the total pressure.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Partial Pressure
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the partial pressure of a gas in a mixture based on its mole fraction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the partial pressure of } \text{N}_2 \text{ in a mixture with } X_{\text{N}_2} = 0.4 \text{ and } P_T = 2.5 \text{ atm.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Mole Fraction
Physical Chemistry.description: Defines the mole fraction of a gas in a mixture.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the mole fraction of } \text{O}_2 \text{ in a mixture with } 0.5 \text{ mol } \text{O}_2 \text{ and } 1.5 \text{ mol } \text{N}_2.

Physical Chemistry.name: Root-Mean-Square Speed
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the root-mean-square speed of gas molecules.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } u_{\text{rms}} \text{ for } \text{N}_2 \text{ (} M = 28.02 \text{ g/mol) at } 300 \text{ K, given } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Kinetic Energy
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the kinetic energy of a single molecule.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the kinetic energy of an } \text{O}_2 \text{ molecule (} m = 5.31 \times 10^{-26} \text{ kg) moving at } 500 \text{ m/s.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
KE &= \frac{1}{2} m u^2 \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cdot 5.31 \times 10^{-26} \cdot (500)^2 \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cdot 5.31 \times 10^{-26} \cdot 250000 \\
&= 6.6375 \times 10^{-21} \text{ J} \\
\text{Thus, the kinetic energy is } 6.64 \times 10^{-21} \text{ J} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Average Kinetic Energy
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the average kinetic energy per gas molecule.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the average kinetic energy of a gas molecule at } 298 \text{ K, given } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K), } N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Van der Waals Equation
Physical Chemistry.formula: \left( P + \frac{a n^2}{V^2} \right) (V - n b) = n RT
Physical Chemistry.description: Equation of state for real gases, accounting for molecular attractions and volume.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the pressure of } 2.0 \text{ mol of } \text{CO}_2 \text{ in a } 5.0 \text{ L container at } 300 \text{ K, given } a = 3.592 \text{ L}^2\cdot\text{atm/mol}^2, b = 0.0427 \text{ L/mol, } R = 0.08206 \text{ L·atm/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\left( P + \frac{a n^2}{V^2} \right) (V - n b) &= n RT \\
\frac{a n^2}{V^2} &= \frac{3.592 \cdot (2.0)^2}{(5.0)^2} = \frac{14.368}{25} = 0.57472 \text{ atm} \\
V - n b &= 5.0 - 2.0 \cdot 0.0427 = 5.0 - 0.0854 = 4.9146 \text{ L} \\
n RT &= 2.0 \cdot 0.08206 \cdot 300 = 49.236 \text{ L·atm} \\
\left( P + 0.57472 \right) \cdot 4.9146 &= 49.236 \\
P + 0.57472 &= \frac{49.236}{4.9146} \approx 10.018 \\
P &= 10.018 - 0.57472 \approx 9.443 \text{ atm} \\
\text{Thus, the pressure is approximately } 9.44 \text{ atm} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Van der Waals Equation for One Mole
Physical Chemistry.description: Van der Waals equation for one mole of a real gas.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the molar volume of } \text{N}_2 \text{ at } 10 \text{ atm and } 300 \text{ K, given } a = 1.390 \text{ L}^2\cdot\text{atm/mol}^2, b = 0.0391 \text{ L/mol, } R = 0.08206 \text{ L·atm/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\left( P + \frac{a}{V_m^2} \right) (V_m - b) &= RT \\
RT &= 0.08206 \cdot 300 = 24.618 \text{ L·atm/mol} \\
b &= 0.0391 \text{ L/mol} \\
\left( 10 + \frac{1.390}{V_m^2} \right) (V_m - 0.0391) &= 24.618 \\
\text{Let } V_m = 2.5 \text{ (trial value)}, \ \frac{1.390}{(2.5)^2} &= \frac{1.390}{6.25} = 0.2224 \text{ atm} \\
V_m - b &= 2.5 - 0.0391 = 2.4609 \text{ L/mol} \\
\left( 10 + 0.2224 \right) \cdot 2.4609 &= 10.2224 \cdot 2.4609 \approx 25.166 \\
\text{Compare: } 25.166 \neq 24.618 \text{ (adjust } V_m \text{ iteratively)} \\
\text{After solving numerically, } V_m \approx 2.465 \text{ L/mol satisfies the equation.} \\
\text{Thus, } V_m \approx 2.47 \text{ L/mol} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Joule-Thomson Coefficient
Physical Chemistry.description: Measures the change in temperature with pressure at constant enthalpy for a real gas.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \mu \text{ for a gas where } \left( \frac{\partial T}{\partial P} \right)_H = 0.25 \text{ K/atm under given conditions.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Enthalpy Change
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the enthalpy change of a reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta H \text{ for a reaction with } H_{\text{products}} = 500 \text{ kJ, } H_{\text{reactants}} = 600 \text{ kJ.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Heat Change
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the heat absorbed or released by a substance.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the heat required to raise } 100 \text{ g of water (} s = 4.18 \text{ J/(g·K)) from } 25^\circ\text{C to } 75^\circ\text{C.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Heat Capacity
Physical Chemistry.description: Defines the heat capacity of a substance.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the heat capacity of } 50 \text{ g of aluminum with } s = 0.897 \text{ J/(g·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Heat Change with Heat Capacity
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates heat change using heat capacity at constant pressure or volume.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the heat absorbed by a substance with } C = 100 \text{ J/K when heated by } 20 \text{ K.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Reaction Enthalpy at Constant Volume
Physical Chemistry.description: Relates heat of reaction to internal energy change at constant volume.

example.problem: \text{If } \Delta E = -50 \text{ kJ for a reaction at constant volume, calculate } q_{\text{rxn}}.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Bomb Calorimeter Heat
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the heat of reaction in a bomb calorimeter.

example.problem: \text{A bomb calorimeter has } q_{\text{water}} = 8000 \text{ J, } q_{\text{bomb}} = 2000 \text{ J. Calculate } q_{\text{rxn}}.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Standard Enthalpy of Reaction
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the standard enthalpy of reaction from standard enthalpies of formation.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^o \text{ for } \text{CH}_4(g) + 2 \text{O}_2(g) \to \text{CO}_2(g) + 2 \text{H}_2\text{O}(l), \text{ given } \Delta H_f^o (\text{CH}_4) = -74.8 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta H_f^o (\text{CO}_2) = -393.5 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta H_f^o (\text{H}_2\text{O}) = -285.8 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta H_f^o (\text{O}_2) = 0 \text{ kJ/mol.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^o &= \sum n \Delta H_f^o (\text{products}) - \sum m \Delta H_f^o (\text{reactants}) \\
&= [1 \cdot (-393.5) + 2 \cdot (-285.8)] - [1 \cdot (-74.8) + 2 \cdot 0] \\
&= [-393.5 - 571.6] - [-74.8] \\
&= -965.1 + 74.8 = -890.3 \text{ kJ/mol} \\
\text{Thus, } \Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^o \approx -890.3 \text{ kJ/mol} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Enthalpy of Solution
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the enthalpy change when an ionic compound dissolves.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta H_{\text{soln}} \text{ for } \text{NaCl, given } \Delta H_{\text{hydr}} = -784 \text{ kJ/mol, } U = 788 \text{ kJ/mol.}

Physical Chemistry.name: First Law of Thermodynamics
Physical Chemistry.description: States that the change in internal energy equals heat added plus work done on the system.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta E \text{ for a system with } q = 500 \text{ J and } w = -200 \text{ J.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Work in Gas Expansion
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates work done during gas expansion at constant pressure.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the work done when a gas expands from } 1.0 \text{ L to } 2.0 \text{ L at } 1.013 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Enthalpy Definition
Physical Chemistry.description: Defines enthalpy as a state function.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } H \text{ for a system with } E = 1000 \text{ J, } P = 1.013 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa, } V = 0.001 \text{ m}^3.

Physical Chemistry.name: Enthalpy Change
Physical Chemistry.description: General form of enthalpy change.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta H \text{ for } \Delta E = 500 \text{ J, } \Delta (PV) = 200 \text{ J.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Enthalpy Change for Gases
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates enthalpy change for gaseous reactions.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta H \text{ for a reaction with } \Delta E = -10000 \text{ J, } \Delta n_g = 2, T = 298 \text{ K, } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Rate of Reaction

variables.\\Delta [A]: Change in concentration of reactant A (mol/L)
variables.\\Delta [B]: Change in concentration of product B (mol/L)

Physical Chemistry.description: Defines the average rate of reaction based on concentration changes.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate of disappearance of } \text{A if } [A] \text{ decreases from } 0.5 \text{ M to } 0.3 \text{ M in } 10 \text{ s.}

Physical Chemistry.name: General Rate Expression
Physical Chemistry.formula: aA + bB \to cC + dD \\ \ \\ \text{rate} = - \frac{1}{a} \frac{\Delta [A]}{\Delta t} = - \frac{1}{b} \frac{\Delta [B]}{\Delta t} = \frac{1}{c} \frac{\Delta [C]}{\Delta t} = \frac{1}{d} \frac{\Delta [D]}{\Delta t}
Physical Chemistry.description: Rate expression for the reaction aA + bB → cC + dD.

example.problem: \text{For } 2\text{A} \to \text{B}, \text{ if } \frac{\Delta [A]}{\Delta t} = -0.04 \text{ M/s, calculate } \frac{\Delta [B]}{\Delta t}.

Physical Chemistry.name: Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: General form of the rate law for a reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate for } k = 0.1 \text{ M}^{-2}\text{s}^{-1}, [A] = 0.2 \text{ M}, [B] = 0.3 \text{ M}, x = 1, y = 2.

Physical Chemistry.name: First-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Rate law for a first-order reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate for a first-order reaction with } k = 0.05 \text{ s}^{-1}, [A] = 0.4 \text{ M.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Integrated First-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes concentration versus time for a first-order reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } [A] \text{ after } 10 \text{ s for } [A]_0 = 1.0 \text{ M, } k = 0.1 \text{ s}^{-1}.

Physical Chemistry.name: Log Form of First-Order
Physical Chemistry.description: Linear form of the first-order rate law for graphing.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \ln [A] \text{ after } 20 \text{ s for } [A]_0 = 2.0 \text{ M, } k = 0.03 \text{ s}^{-1}.

Physical Chemistry.name: Half-Life for First-Order
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the time for half the reactant to disappear in a first-order reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the half-life for a first-order reaction with } k = 0.02 \text{ s}^{-1}.

Physical Chemistry.name: Second-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Rate law for a second-order reaction with respect to A.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate for } k = 0.5 \text{ M}^{-1}\text{s}^{-1}, [A] = 0.1 \text{ M.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Integrated Second-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes 1/[A] versus time for a second-order reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } [A] \text{ after } 100 \text{ s for } [A]_0 = 0.2 \text{ M, } k = 0.01 \text{ M}^{-1}\text{s}^{-1}.
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{[A]} &= \frac{1}{[A]_0} + kt \\
&= \frac{1}{0.2} + 0.01 \cdot 100 \\
&= 5 + 1 = 6 \text{ M}^{-1} \\
[A] &= \frac{1}{6} \approx 0.1667 \text{ M} \\
\text{Thus, } [A] \approx 0.167 \text{ M} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Half-Life for Second-Order
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the half-life for a second-order reaction, dependent on initial concentration.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the half-life for } k = 0.05 \text{ M}^{-1}\text{s}^{-1}, [A]_0 = 0.4 \text{ M.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Zero-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes a constant reaction rate independent of concentration.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate for a zero-order reaction with } k = 0.01 \text{ M/s.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Integrated Zero-Order Rate Law
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes concentration versus time for a zero-order reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } [A] \text{ after } 30 \text{ s for } [A]_0 = 0.5 \text{ M, } k = 0.01 \text{ M/s.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Arrhenius Equation
Physical Chemistry.description: Describes the temperature dependence of the rate constant.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } k \text{ for } A = 2 \times 10^{10} \text{ s}^{-1}, E_a = 50 \text{ kJ/mol}, T = 298 \text{ K, } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
E_a &= 50 \times 10^3 \text{ J/mol} \\
\frac{E_a}{RT} &= \frac{50000}{8.314 \cdot 298} \approx 20.19 \\
k &= A e^{-E_a / RT} = 2 \times 10^{10} \cdot e^{-20.19} \\
&= 2 \times 10^{10} \cdot 1.75 \times 10^{-9} \approx 0.035 \text{ s}^{-1} \\
\text{Thus, } k \approx 0.035 \text{ s}^{-1} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Log Form of Arrhenius
Physical Chemistry.description: Linear form of the Arrhenius equation for graphing.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \ln k \text{ for } A = 1 \times 10^{12} \text{ s}^{-1}, E_a = 60 \text{ kJ/mol}, T = 300 \text{ K, } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Two-Temperature Arrhenius
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates activation energy or rate constant at different temperatures.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } E_a \text{ if } k_2 = 0.02 \text{ s}^{-1}, k_1 = 0.01 \text{ s}^{-1}, T_1 = 300 \text{ K}, T_2 = 310 \text{ K, } R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\ln \frac{k_2}{k_1} &= \ln \frac{0.02}{0.01} = \ln 2 \approx 0.693 \\
\frac{1}{T_1} - \frac{1}{T_2} &= \frac{1}{300} - \frac{1}{310} \approx 0.003333 - 0.003226 = 0.000107 \text{ K}^{-1} \\
0.693 &= \frac{E_a}{8.314} \cdot 0.000107 \\
E_a &= \frac{0.693 \cdot 8.314}{0.000107} \approx 53850 \text{ J/mol} = 53.85 \text{ kJ/mol} \\
\text{Thus, } E_a \approx 53.85 \text{ kJ/mol} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Equilibrium Constant Kc
Physical Chemistry.description: Equilibrium constant for the reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } K_c \text{ for } 2\text{A} + \text{B} \rightleftharpoons \text{C}, \text{ with } [A] = 0.1 \text{ M}, [B] = 0.2 \text{ M}, [C] = 0.5 \text{ M at equilibrium.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Equilibrium Constant Kp
Physical Chemistry.description: Equilibrium constant for gaseous reactions in terms of partial pressures.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } K_p \text{ for } 2\text{NO}(g) \rightleftharpoons \text{N}_2(g) + \text{O}_2(g), \text{ with } P_{\text{NO}} = 0.1 \text{ atm}, P_{\text{N}_2} = 0.4 \text{ atm}, P_{\text{O}_2} = 0.3 \text{ atm.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Relation Kp and Kc
Physical Chemistry.description: Relates Kp and Kc for gaseous reactions.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } K_p \text{ for } \text{N}_2(g) + 3\text{H}_2(g) \rightleftharpoons 2\text{NH}_3(g), \text{ with } K_c = 0.05, T = 298 \text{ K, } R = 0.08206 \text{ L·atm/(mol·K).}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\Delta n &= 2 - (1 + 3) = -2 \\
RT &= 0.08206 \cdot 298 \approx 24.45388 \\
K_p &= K_c (RT)^{\Delta n} = 0.05 \cdot (24.45388)^{-2} \\
&= 0.05 \cdot \frac{1}{598.391} \approx 8.36 \times 10^{-5} \\
\text{Thus, } K_p \approx 8.36 \times 10^{-5} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Physical Chemistry.name: Multiple Equilibrium K
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the overall equilibrium constant for consecutive equilibria.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } K \text{ for two steps with } K_1 = 2.0, K_2 = 3.0.

Physical Chemistry.name: pH Definition
Physical Chemistry.description: Measures the acidity of a solution.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the pH of a solution with } [H^+] = 1.0 \times 10^{-3} \text{ M.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Solubility Product Ksp
Physical Chemistry.description: Solubility product for AgCl(s) ⇌ Ag^+(aq) + Cl^-(aq).

example.problem: \text{Calculate } K_{\text{sp}} \text{ for } \text{AgCl if } [\text{Ag}^+] = [\text{Cl}^-] = 1.34 \times 10^{-5} \text{ M.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Entropy Change
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the entropy change for a process.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta S \text{ if } S_f = 200 \text{ J/(mol·K), } S_i = 150 \text{ J/(mol·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Standard Entropy of Reaction
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the standard entropy change from standard entropies.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta S_{\text{rxn}}^o \text{ for } \text{C}(s) + \text{O}_2(g) \to \text{CO}_2(g), \text{ with } S^o (\text{C}) = 5.7 \text{ J/(mol·K)}, S^o (\text{O}_2) = 205.0 \text{ J/(mol·K)}, S^o (\text{CO}_2) = 213.6 \text{ J/(mol·K).}

Physical Chemistry.name: Entropy Change in Surroundings
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the entropy change in the surroundings at constant temperature.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta S_{\text{surr}} \text{ for } \Delta H_{\text{sys}} = -40000 \text{ J/mol, } T = 298 \text{ K.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Gibbs Free Energy
Physical Chemistry.description: Defines Gibbs free energy as a state function.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } G \text{ for } H = 100 \text{ kJ/mol}, S = 200 \text{ J/(mol·K)}, T = 298 \text{ K.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Gibbs Free Energy Change
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates Gibbs free energy change at constant temperature.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta G \text{ for } \Delta H = -50 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta S = 100 \text{ J/(mol·K)}, T = 298 \text{ K.}

Physical Chemistry.name: Standard Free Energy Change
Physical Chemistry.description: Calculates the standard free energy change from standard free energies of formation.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \Delta G^o \text{ for } \text{CH}_4(g) + 2 \text{O}_2(g) \to \text{CO}_2(g) + 2 \text{H}_2\text{O}(l), \text{ given } \Delta G_f^o (\text{CH}_4) = -50.8 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta G_f^o (\text{O}_2) = 0 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta G_f^o (\text{CO}_2) = -394.4 \text{ kJ/mol}, \Delta G_f^o (\text{H}_2\text{O}) = -237.2 \text{ kJ/mol.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^o &= \sum n \Delta G_f^o (\text{products}) - \sum m \Delta G_f^o (\text{reactants}) \\
&= [1 \cdot (-394.4) + 2 \cdot (-237.2)] - [1 \cdot (-50.8) + 2 \cdot 0] \\
&= [-394.4 - 474.4] - [-50.8] \\
&= -868.8 + 50.8 = -818 \text{ kJ/mol} \\
\text{Thus, } \Delta G^o = -818 \text{ kJ/mol} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}
